div1.head: Jim to M. Paul Rockwell June 24th 1915
div1.p: Eh, mon brave, where’s that long letter you were going to write, promised in the last I have received from you which was written four days after your return from Reimes [sic]? Does the line “Am expecting Jeanne to Paris today” explain why I haven’t had the pleasure? Indirectly I have heard that you’re still up and doing from Marcelle G. and the Vicomte. You probably know he sent me a letter. I was quite floored with the compliment of getting such a delightful personal letter from him. It was fine of him to write to me. I tried to send an answer that would give him an idea of how much I appreciated his letter, but I’m afraid it sounded quite stiff and artificial, for I felt I had to be sort of formal.

The staff car is expected out to day and I shall send this letter in to be mailed from Paris. There isn’t much news. There has been no fighting going on here at all ^of late. Some days we handle fifty wounded only, tho [sic] there will be spells [‘when’ scratched out] during an hour or two — when the crapouillot and grenade work has been lively, and there will be a lot of rush work. Last night a great many were wounded by a short but fierce bombardment of the trenches by 210 s. Bad head wounds too,
for out of eleven operations ten died, as the doctors told us this morning. One fellow died in my car before I could get him to the hospital.

We are to be given the work of the adjacent division as well as the one we are now attached to and when that service starts we will go on beyond Auberge St. Pierre [sp?], our last point of call at present, to Feyen Hage [sp?], Leiney [sp?] and Flirey [sp?]. On that road the Germans have a nice trick of dropping four shells at once, forming a square so to speak, and it would be quite delightful, to say the least, to be in the Center. They’ve left us alone in Pont a Mousson itself for over four days now.

Captain Watts, the Australian aviator in the French service, and Noel, the famous military flier, ran down from their base near Toul to lunch with us this noon. Both of them have done wonders in this war. Its rather queer to meet men on the ground who you have watched being fired on in the air. Do you know what secteur Thaw is working in? I hear he’s quartered at Nancy but don’t know what he covers. I forgot to ask.

There is to be a week more of nothing doing and then, depending somewhat on the result of the northern movement, we are to have one hell of a an attack in this
place. Watts expects to come down and rest with us after the work is over. You ought to hear him on England. He has no patience at all with the way they’re doing. Too many shirkers in the small crowd they have out. A Lord something or other he knows in England is yelling his lungs out about fellows recruiting, saying his son is fighting for “King & Country”, but Watts ran into said K & C fighter in Paris running some swank automobile supply system.

By the way, please advise me about the kind of stuff you think might sell. I mean give me a line on the material to look for; treatment, length, etc. and I’ll cook up a couple of samples from the brand of copy one gets here and you can tell me whether I’m right or wrong. I have just finished a 7,000 word article on the American section here that I know would be of interest in the States but its for the Ambulance Authorities who asked me to write it up for them. Its to be taken to the censor and then sent, God knows where. Your Sydney Adamson route sounds fine. If it was so rotten he would be ashamed of putting his name au dessous we could fake another. I might not
be able to send in anything worth while, but then there’s no use ^not trying. You and Adamson & I could figure out a whack up providing the stuff sells.

In a letter from Arthur Page, editor of World’s Work, he tells me that even Arno Dosch (Fleurot’s) stuff is now hard to sell — that people now pass by unnoticed things that a year ago thrilled them to the core and that now they are wondering what’s coming next and not interested in what’s gone before. Too bad about em, isn’t it? I haven’t sent Page anything from out here yet.

When Walls and Noel were here, (You note I have continued the letter from the other day) Salisbury, our boss, and a couple of other fellows took them up to the trenches. Noel said he knew the way perfectly from his aerial observations. Well they got on up to the Quart en Reserve and then got lost and wandered off into a section where artillery has practically levelled [sic] the ground. They were finally wandering around in an abandoned area 200 meters from the Germans. They knew they were exposed but not until later did they find out how close they were. Well the nuts stood up there and had an argument. Watts with glaring Captain’s galons and several gold wings on him began giving Noel hell for leading them the wrong way. They
argued out there for a long time. No one can understand why the crowd wasn’t shot. Three looked like English and two were French officers. Finally they crawled back, tho [sic] what was left of the trenches didn’t afford but six inches or less of cover and eventually got into the boyau running to the 1st line which is but 17 meters from the Boches. A shell had just landed there and they had to crawl over some dead bodies. I know the place, Le Col de Cygne, I was up there a few weeks ago but with an officer and didn’t get lost. We took the fliers back to their grounds near Toul and they began telling about their visit to the trenches with all the excitement we would manifest should we recount a flight in one of their machines. I’m going to try for a ride with Noel and hope to get it. Watts has been hit 56 times — that is his machine has. You know its fortunate in the extreme that we are placed as we are. We get an intimate knowledge of all phases and it makes it all very interesting. We really see more of the details of the whole business than lots of French officers. Keep that observation under your hat please. Its only because we’ve make good tho [sic] that they let us have the cinch we enjoy.
Last night I was on duty back at Dieulouard where every ten days one has a turn, and ran across some fellows I know from an Algerian battery in Bois le Pretre. We formed up a concert. We sat around a long table in the garden of some popote and beat time while the Algerians chanted. There was an Arab there that was a wonder on the old two toned songs. That language sounds as if one were trying to open an old rusty lock and it was breaking. Felt at home tho [sic] for the rest were as rotten in French as I am. It had rained during the day, washing the air, and the light of the full moon was glorious. Finally a girl, the prettiest I’ve seen out this way, slipped onto the scene. I don’t know where she came from, but she looked strangely out of place in her fluffy white dress, flower bordered apron and tiny pumps, in the middle of our Algerian aggregation. Finally we got accustomed to her and I felt as if we were in northern Africa and she some fair houri. One of the men borrowed her shawl, produced a couple of handkerchiefs in place of veils and to the accompaniment of chanting and measured beats proceeded to execute a danse de ventre. It was great. One of the fellows got marvelous cymbal
effects out of a beer bottle with a swinging cap and a door for a sounding board. This morning a fellow named Smith, who was on duty with me, and I motored the crowd back to their battery. Well we’re running a war de luxe if nothing else. Very few of the fellows in the Artillery ever seem to get hurt. When they do its an event. Everyone stops your car on the way down and takes a look at the gunner.

Yes, old boy, I reckon you’re right when you see no immediate ending to the war, and as far as Italy is concerned I don’t think she helps much. You see she want Trieste and Trente [sic]. Austria couldn’t just quietly hand the section over to her and so Italy goes to war about it. Austria being in the position of heads I win & tails you lose puts up a fake fight to hold her honor and lets Italy take what she wants with as little a loss as possible. I am very much afraid that having occupied the area in question Italy will proceed to quit. To do on I understand she wants, as a reward Tunisia. Hell of a nerve, when you consider
France made Italy what she is to day. The whole show seems up into France and Russia against Germany and Austria - Hungary with the aid of England’s sea power to help our Allies. The rest counts off. Japan of course counts for nothing and Serbia, Belgium & Montenegro are more than balanced by Turkey. When you figure the thing out in light of preparations; the comparative strength of each, and what should have been accomplished, why France and Russia have beaten the devil out of Germany and Austria. Grand Meme c’est dure cette sale guerre. And a few other oft repeated formulas such as “Quand ^serait [sp?] fini, cette guerre?” & “Qui j’aimerais bien de voir la fin, c’est longue, c’est dure.”

closer.salute: Hope to hear from you soon old legionaire [sic].
